COU.MemberMetadata:
..ISR..Data source(s) used

The statistical data for Israel are supplied by and under the responsibility of the relevant Israeli authorities. The use of such data by the OECD is without prejudice to the status of the Golan Heights, East Jerusalem and Israeli settlements in the West Bank under the terms of international law.

..TWN..Data source(s) used

For Chinese Taipei, we use data from national statistical office, which are publicly available on its official website. All the variables described above can be found in GDP by Kind of Activities and GNP by Expenditures tables.

IND.MemberName: Textiles, textile products, leather and footwear
Wood, paper, paper products, printing and publishing

Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Viet Nam.

...CYP.Data source(s) used

1. Footnote by Turkey: The information in this document with reference to « Cyprus » relates to the southern part of the Island. There is no single authority representing both Turkish and Greek Cypriot people on the Island. Turkey recognizes the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC). Until a lasting and equitable solution is found within the context of United Nations, Turkey shall preserve its position concerning the “Cyprus issue”. <br> <br> 2. Footnote by all the European Union Member States of the OECD and the European Union: The Republic of Cyprus is recognized by all members of the United Nations with the exception of Turkey. The information in this document relates to the area under the effective control of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus.

Japan, Korea, China, Chinese Taipei, Hong Kong.

Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom.

European Union 15 plus Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Romania, Slovak Republic, Slovenia.

...ISR.Data source(s) used

The statistical data for Israel are supplied by and under the responsibility of the relevant Israeli authorities. The use of such data by the OECD is without prejudice to the status of the Golan Heights, East Jerusalem and Israeli settlements in the West Bank under the terms of international law.

Canada, Mexico, United States.

...OECD.Data source(s) used

This aggregate includes Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Chile, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Korea, Luxembourg, Mexico, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United Kingdom, the United States.

...TWN.Data source(s) used

For Chinese Taipei, we use data from national statistical office, which are publicly available on its official website. All the variables described above can be found in GDP by Kind of Activities and GNP by Expenditures tables.

VAR.MemberName: Gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR....Data source(s) used

All variables are consistent with official National Accounts estimates of total gross trade balances (total exports minus total imports) and GDP estimates. Adjustments are made to account for the presence of re-exports in the official statistics. In practice, this means estimates of re-exports are removed from official National Accounts estimates of trade flows. Estimates by Industry are based on the balanced pattern of trade derived within the global input-output database. <br>Bilateral gross trade flows (between partner countries) of exports and imports are not shown as current official statistics on bilateral trade are not globally coherent. The global input-output table underlying the TiVA database imposes coherence in bilateral gross flows, which may be released in future database releases after consultation with national statistics institutes (NSIs). <br>The underlying gross bilateral trade statistics used to arrive at the balanced picture of trade in the TiVA database are however available for both goods (OECD's Bilateral Trade by Industry and End-Use database BTDIxE) and services (OECD's Trade in Services by Partner Country database, TISP) and can be found on the OECD's statistics portal OECD.Stat.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Gross exports

VAR.MemberName: Direct domestic industry value added content of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_DDC....Data source(s) used

This reflects the direct contribution made by an industry in producing a good or service for export.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Direct domestic industry value added content of gross exports

VAR.MemberName: Direct domestic service industry value added content of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_DDC_SV....Data source(s) used

This reflects the direct services value-added made by an industry in producing a good or service for export. By definition it will be zero for all non-services industries.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Direct domestic service industry value added content of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Direct domestic industry value added share of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_DDCSH....Data source(s) used

The share reflects how much value-added is generated in an industry per unit of its total gross exports.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Direct domestic industry value added share of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Domestic value added (by source industry) embodied in gross exports
Foreign value added content of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_FVA....Data source(s) used

This reflects the import content of exports i.e. the foreign value-added coming from imports that are embodied in exports - broken down by country of origin.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Foreign value added content of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Origin country

VAR.MemberName: Foreign services value added content of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_FVA_SV....Data source(s) used

This reflects the foreign services value-added embodied in imports broken down by country of origin.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Foreign services value added content of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Foreign value added share of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_FVASH....Data source(s) used

This is equivalent to 1 minus EXGRDVA_EX

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Foreign value added share of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Gross exports as a % of GDP (total value added)
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_GDP....Data source(s) used

All variables are consistent with official National Accounts estimates of total gross trade balances (total exports minus total imports) and GDP estimates. Adjustments are made to account for the presence of re-exports in the official statistics. In practice, this means estimates of re-exports are removed from official National Accounts estimates of trade flows. Estimates by Industry are based on the balanced pattern of trade derived within the global input-output database. <br>Bilateral gross trade flows (between partner countries) of exports and imports are not shown as current official statistics on bilateral trade are not globally coherent. The global input-output table underlying the TiVA database imposes coherence in bilateral gross flows, which may be released in future database releases after consultation with national statistics institutes (NSIs). <br>The underlying gross bilateral trade statistics used to arrive at the balanced picture of trade in the TiVA database are however available for both goods (OECD's Bilateral Trade by Industry and End-Use database BTDIxE) and services (OECD's Trade in Services by Partner Country database, TISP) and can be found on the OECD's statistics portal OECD.Stat.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Gross exports as a % of GDP (total value added)

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: importing country

VAR.MemberName: Indirect domestic content of gross exports (originating from domestic intermediates)
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_IDC....Data source(s) used

This reflects the indirect contribution of domestic supplier industries made through domestic (upstream) transactions.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Indirect domestic content of gross exports (originating from domestic intermediates)

VAR.MemberName: Indirect domestic services content of gross exports (originating from domestic intermediates)
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_IDC_SV....Data source(s) used

This reflects the indirect contribution of domestic service suppliers made through domestic (upstream) transactions, for exports.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Indirect domestic services content of gross exports (originating from domestic intermediates)

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Indirect domestic share of gross exports (originating from domestic intermediates)
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_IDCSH....Data source(s) used

The share reflects the value-added created in upstream industries providing domestic inputs to the exporting industry.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Indirect domestic share of gross exports (originating from domestic intermediates)

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Re-imported domestic value added content of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_RIM....Data source(s) used

This reflects the domestic value-added that was exported in goods and services used to produce the intermediate imports of goods and services used by the industry in question.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Re-imported domestic value added content of gross exports

VAR.MemberName: Re-imported domestic services value added content of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_RIM_SV....Data source(s) used

This reflects the domestic services value-added that was exported in goods and services used to produce the intermediate imports of goods and services used by the industry in question.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Re-imported domestic services value added content of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Re-imported domestic value added share of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGR_RIMSH....Data source(s) used

The share reflects the value-added created in upstream domestic industries providing indirect intermediate inputs, via international, as opposed to domestic, value-chains to the industry in question. The indicator provides a measure of how protectionist measures may impact on domestic industries that provide inputs to imports.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Re-imported domestic value added share of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: Importing country

VAR.MemberName: Domestic value added embodied in gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGRDVA....Data source(s) used

Total Domestic value-added content of exports. This consists of three components: EXGR_DDC, EXGR_IDC and EXGR_RIM.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Domestic value added embodied in gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: importing country

VAR.MemberName: Value Added Export Ratio - total domestic value added share of gross exports, %
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGRDVA_EX....Data source(s) used

This reflects the domestic value-added embodied in exports as a per cent of exports. It provides a simple measure that illustrates how much value-added is generated throughout the economy for a given unit of exports. The lower the ratio the higher the foreign content and so the higher the importance of imports to exports.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Value Added Export Ratio - total domestic value added share of gross exports, %

VAR.MemberName: Gross exports - partner shares, %
VAR.MemberMetadata:
EXGRSH....Data source(s) used

All variables are consistent with official National Accounts estimates of total gross trade balances (total exports minus total imports) and GDP estimates. Adjustments are made to account for the presence of re-exports in the official statistics. In practice, this means estimates of re-exports are removed from official National Accounts estimates of trade flows. Estimates by Industry are based on the balanced pattern of trade derived within the global input-output database. <br>Bilateral gross trade flows (between partner countries) of exports and imports are not shown as current official statistics on bilateral trade are not globally coherent. The global input-output table underlying the TiVA database imposes coherence in bilateral gross flows, which may be released in future database releases after consultation with national statistics institutes (NSIs). <br>The underlying gross bilateral trade statistics used to arrive at the balanced picture of trade in the TiVA database are however available for both goods (OECD's Bilateral Trade by Industry and End-Use database BTDIxE) and services (OECD's Trade in Services by Partner Country database, TISP) and can be found on the OECD's statistics portal OECD.Stat.

Unit of measure used

%

VAR.MemberName: Domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand
VAR.MemberMetadata:
FDDVA....Data source(s) used

Value-Added embodied in Foreign Final Domestic Demand shows how industries export value both through direct final exports and via indirect exports of intermediates through other countries to foreign final consumers (households, charities, government, and as investment). They reflect how industries (upstream in a value-chain) are connected to consumers in other countries, even where no direct trade relationship exists. The indicator illustrates therefore the full upstream impact of final demand in foreign markets to domestic output. It can most readily be interpreted as 'exports of value-added'.

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: final destination

VAR.MemberName: Export Ratio - Domestic value added in final demand
VAR.MemberMetadata:
FDDVA_EX....Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Value Added Export Ratio - total domestic value added in foreign final demand as % of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: final destination

VAR.MemberName: Domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand as a % of GDP (total value added)
VAR.MemberMetadata:
FDDVA_GDP....Data source(s) used

Value-Added embodied in Foreign Final Domestic Demand shows how industries export value both through direct final exports and via indirect exports of intermediates through other countries to foreign final consumers (households, charities, government, and as investment). They reflect how industries (upstream in a value-chain) are connected to consumers in other countries, even where no direct trade relationship exists. The indicator illustrates therefore the full upstream impact of final demand in foreign markets to domestic output. It can most readily be interpreted as 'exports of value-added'.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand as a % of GDP (total value added)

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: final destination

VAR.MemberName: Domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand - partner shares, % of total domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand
VAR.MemberMetadata:
FDDVASH....Data source(s) used

Value-Added embodied in Foreign Final Domestic Demand shows how industries export value both through direct final exports and via indirect exports of intermediates through other countries to foreign final consumers (households, charities, government, and as investment). They reflect how industries (upstream in a value-chain) are connected to consumers in other countries, even where no direct trade relationship exists. The indicator illustrates therefore the full upstream impact of final demand in foreign markets to domestic output. It can most readily be interpreted as 'exports of value-added'.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand - partner shares, % of total domestic value added embodied in foreign final demand

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: final destination

VAR.MemberName: Foreign value added embodied in domestic final demand
VAR.MemberMetadata:
FDFVA....Data source(s) used

Foreign Value-Added embodied in Final Domestic Demand shows for a final good or service (purchased by households, government, non-profit institutions serving households, or as investment) where foreign value-added originates. It is the 'import' corollary of FDDVA and shows how industries abroad (upstream in a value-chain) are connected to consumers at home, even where no direct trade relationship exists. It can most readily be interpreted as 'imports of value-added'

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Foreign value added embodied in domestic final demand

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: origin country

VAR.MemberName: Foreign value added embodied in domestic final demand as a % of GDP (total value added)
VAR.MemberMetadata:
FDFVA_GDP....Data source(s) used

Foreign Value-Added embodied in Final Domestic Demand shows for a final good or service (purchased by households, government, non-profit institutions serving households, or as investment) where foreign value-added originates. It is the 'import' corollary of FDDVA and shows how industries abroad (upstream in a value-chain) are connected to consumers at home, even where no direct trade relationship exists. It can most readily be interpreted as 'imports of value-added'

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Foreign value added embodied in domestic final demand as a % of GDP (total value added)

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: origin country

VAR.MemberName: Foreign value added embodied in domestic final demand - partner shares, % of total foreign value added in domestic final demand
VAR.MemberMetadata:
FDFVASH....Data source(s) used

Foreign Value-Added embodied in Final Domestic Demand shows for a final good or service (purchased by households, government, non-profit institutions serving households, or as investment) where foreign value-added originates. It is the 'import' corollary of FDDVA and shows how industries abroad (upstream in a value-chain) are connected to consumers at home, even where no direct trade relationship exists. It can most readily be interpreted as 'imports of value-added'

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Foreign value added embodied in domestic final demand - partner shares, % of total foreign value added in domestic final demand

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: origin country

All variables are consistent with official National Accounts estimates of total gross trade balances (total exports minus total imports) and GDP estimates. Adjustments are made to account for the presence of re-exports in the official statistics. In practice, this means estimates of re-exports are removed from official National Accounts estimates of trade flows. Estimates by Industry are based on the balanced pattern of trade derived within the global input-output database. <br>Bilateral gross trade flows (between partner countries) of exports and imports are not shown as current official statistics on bilateral trade are not globally coherent. The global input-output table underlying the TiVA database imposes coherence in bilateral gross flows, which may be released in future database releases after consultation with national statistics institutes (NSIs). <br>The underlying gross bilateral trade statistics used to arrive at the balanced picture of trade in the TiVA database are however available for both goods (OECD's Bilateral Trade by Industry and End-Use database BTDIxE) and services (OECD's Trade in Services by Partner Country database, TISP) and can be found on the OECD's statistics portal OECD.Stat.

USD million

Key statistical concept

Gross imports

Adjustments are made to account for the presence of re-exports in the official statistics. In practice, this means estimates of re-exports are removed from official National Accounts estimates of trade flows. RCA_EXGRDVA....Data source(s) used

Index

index

VAR.MemberName: Re-exported intermediates as a % of total intermediate imports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
REI....Data source(s) used

This reflects the share of intermediate imports that are used (indirectly and directly) in producing goods and services for export, as a per cent of total intermediate imports (by import category). The indicator provides a measure of the importance of intermediate imports to produce goods and services for export and their role as a source of international competiveness.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Re-exported intermediates as a % of total intermediate imports

VAR.MemberName: Services value added embodied in foreign final demand
VAR.MemberMetadata:
SERV_VAFD....Data source(s) used

Domestic Services Value-Added embodied in Foreign Final Domestic Demand, by origin country and origin industry, as a percentage of total final demand in the importing country

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Services value added embodied in foreign final demand, as % of foreign final demand

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: origin country

VAR.MemberName: Services value added embodied in gross exports by source country, as % of gross exports
VAR.MemberMetadata:
SERV_VAGR....Data source(s) used

Total Domestic value-added content of exports is broken down into three components, defined as EXGR_DDC_SV, EXGR_IDC_SV and EXGR_RIM_SV. Their definitions follow from their whole economy counterparts defined as EXGR_DDC, EXGR_IDC and EXGR_RIM.

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Services value added embodied in gross exports by source country, as % of gross exports

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: origin country

VAR.MemberName: Gross trade surplus
VAR.MemberMetadata:
TSGR....Data source(s) used

TSGR is equivalent to EXGR minus IMGR. Bilateral trade positions in TSGR are also shown in the TiVA database. These bilateral trade balances broadly align with 'official' bilateral trade balances produced by NSIs. However there are often differences between TiVA estimates and these 'official' estimates'. These reflect: <br>- Treatment of re-exports and transit trade through e.g. Netherlands, Hong Kong, China, Singapore and NAFTA. <br>- Global inconsistencies between exports and imports of trade in goods and services between partner countries, reported in official statistics. <br>- Coverage and quality issues, particularly in official bilateral trade in services statistics, such as missing data. <br>The main focus for bilateral trade balances in the TIVA database should be on differences between TSGR and TSVAFD (see TSVAFD-TSGR).

Unit of measure used

USD million

Key statistical concept

Gross trade surplus

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: importing country

VAR.MemberName: Gross trade surplus as a % of GDP (total value added)
VAR.MemberMetadata:
TSGR_GDP....Data source(s) used

TSGR is equivalent to EXGR minus IMGR. Bilateral trade positions in TSGR are also shown in the TiVA database. These bilateral trade balances broadly align with 'official' bilateral trade balances produced by NSIs. However there are often differences between TiVA estimates and these 'official' estimates'. These reflect: <br>- Treatment of re-exports and transit trade through e.g. Netherlands, Hong Kong, China, Singapore and NAFTA. <br>- Global inconsistencies between exports and imports of trade in goods and services between partner countries, reported in official statistics. <br>- Coverage and quality issues, particularly in official bilateral trade in services statistics, such as missing data. <br>The main focus for bilateral trade balances in the TIVA database should be on differences between TSGR and TSVAFD (see TSVAFD-TSGR).

Unit of measure used

%

Key statistical concept

Gross trade surplus as a % of GDP (total value added)

Other comments

Information on Partner dimension: importing country

The information in this document relates to the area under the effective control of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus.

Japan, Korea, China, Chinese Taipei, Hong Kong.

..EU15...Data source(s) used

Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom.

European Union 15 plus Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Romania, Slovak Republic, Slovenia.

..ISR...Data source(s) used

The statistical data for Israel are supplied by and under the responsibility of the relevant Israeli authorities. The use of such data by the OECD is without prejudice to the status of the Golan Heights, East Jerusalem and Israeli settlements in the West Bank under the terms of international law.

..NAFTA...Data source(s) used

Canada, Mexico, United States.

..OECD...Data source(s) used

This aggregate includes Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Chile, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Korea, Luxembourg, Mexico, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United Kingdom, the United States.

..Z_ASIA...Data source(s) used

..Z_EUR...Data source(s) used

This aggregates includes EU27 countries plus Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Turkey and the Russian Federation.

Australia, Israel, New Zealand, India, Saudi Arabia, South Africa and Rest of the World.

..Z_SAM...Data source(s) used

Argentina, Brazil and Chile.
